data.title: Selected artists for Brazil's Botanical Art Worldwide Exhibition (BAW#2)
data.meta_description: Botanical Worldwide Art Exhibition in Brazil: About the botanical artworks and artists selected for the exhibition in 2018.
data.text:
This post is about the selected botanical artworks (plants) and their artists included in the Brazilian contribution to the Botanical Art Worldwide Exhibition to be held in 2018.

The exhibition will be held in the Exhibition Room at the Botanical Garden of Curitiba (Portuguese: Jardim Botânico de Curitiba)

Jardim Botânico de Curitiba, Paraná, Brasil (Botanical garden Of Curitiba, Paraná state, southern Brazil)

65 artists submitted 143 artworks. From these the Jury selected 60 botanical artworks for the exhibition.

The jury deciding the selection had members representing both botanical art and botany as follows:

Júri Artístico: Dulce Nascimento; Rosanne Quintella; Christina Maria Klas and Marcos Silva-Ferra

Júri Botânico: Andrea Costa (Assistente Igor Musauer Kessous), Paulo Labiak and Mirian Kaehler

Euterpe edulis by Diana Carneiro

Selected Artworks and Artists

​

The selected artworks were announced last week and are listed below

- alongside the names of the botanical artists who created them

The names of the selected artists are listed in alphabetical order​ by surname - with a mini profile based on what's available online

Their location in Brazil is indicated after their name if known

Those who have been Margaret Mee Scholars are highlighted

If available/known, their website (or a website showing their work or Facebook page) is embedded in their name - so you can take a look at their artwork if so inclined.

Included in this post are images of artwork selected for the exhibition which indicate to me that this is going to be an exhibition with a very high standard. Three of these were created by three of the members of the Steering Committee.

READ MORE about the leading botanical artists in Brazil plus the Margaret Mee Scholars (indicated with an * below) on my webpage dedicated to the Botanical Artists in South America. This is as yet incomplete and I'm hoping I'll be adding to it from some of the artists listed below to the page.

Alex Araújo

Catasetum rolfeanum

Alex has a passion for both plants and design and has worked as an independent botanical illustrator for 13 years. He's contributed to a number of projects related to environmental preservation.

'Catasetum rolfeanum' Copyright Alex Araújo

Ana Maria Aviotti

Tibouchina pulchra

Luiz Carlos Berri (Lives Copacabana in Rio de Janeiro)

Paubrasila echinata (see below)

Erythroxylum pulcrum

Assistant editor of Art at one of Rio de Janeiro's most respected newspapers Jornal O Dia for 17 years (1999 to 2017). Studied botanical illustration at Rio de Janeiro Botanical Garden Research Institute, National School of Tropical Botany, Horto (2016-2017). Exhibited four pen and ink illustrations of the species: Paubrasilia echinata and Erythroxylum pulchrum at the exhibition entitled "Botanical Art - RIO" in 68th National Botanical Congress, Rio de Janeiro, Brasil. Currently an intern in botanical illustration at the Research Institute of the Botanical Garden of Rio de Janeiro, for Dr. Massimo G. Bovini. September 2017 (ending February 2018).

'Paubrasila echinata' pen and ink Copyright Luiz Carlos Berri

Fatima Bini (Curitiba, Brazil)

Allamanda schottii

Catasetum fimbriatum

Formerly a botanical illustrator at the Centro de Ilustração Botânica do Paraná which she now manages

Alessandro Candido *

Bauhinia forficata

Cattleya schilleriana1 (SEE BELOW)

Aechmea recurvata

b Iretama-Paraná; Lives Curitiba, Brazil. Works as a botanical illustrator. Graduated in Biological Sciences from CEI- Integrated Educational Center of Campo Mourao. Commenced scientific illustration in May 2014 at Paraná Botanical Illustration Center. Margaret Mee Scholar in 2016. Currently working on a series of endemic plants, endangered or extinct in Brazil.

​Diana Carneiro * (Curitiba) - (MM Scholar 1997)

Euterpe edulis (SEE ABOVE - at beginning of listing)

Bignonias venenosas

Asplenium truncorum

Founder member of the Paraná Botanical Illustration Center (CIBP) and organizer of the Open Course Design Botanical Illustration where she also teaches. Steering Group Member of the National Union of Scientific Illustrators (UNIC). Has work in several collections and various scientific publications.

Ana Deliberador - Former Ilustradora at Centro de Ilustração Botânica do Paraná

Bixa orellana

Bertholletia excelsa

Epidendrum secundum

Cassia Dias

Eichhornia crassipes

Passiflora alata

Jamile Elias Dib - Lives in Olhos-D Água; originally from Brasília, Brazil

Xylopsia aromatica

Sicana odorifera​

Carmen Fidalgo

Billbergia amoena

Zenilton de Jesus Gayoso Miranda - scientific botanical illustrator

Tillandsia barrosoe

Tillandsia streptocarpa

Ivone Gradowski

Bactris gasipaes

Botanic Illustrator - Trained initially as a lawyer. She studied for a diploma in botanical illustration at the Botanical Illustration Center of Paraná (2010/2011). Achieved a Distinction in her SBA Distance Learning Diploma completed in 2015. Member of the American (ASBA), French SFIB) and UK (SBA) Societies of Botanical Artists. She has exhibited her botanical artwork in Curitiba, London, Paris, Courson, Picardie.

Bactris gasipaes by Ivone Gradowski

Lais C. Licheski (b. Curitiba, where she lives and works).

Verbena rigida_verbena

Ananas comosos_abacaxi

Graphic designer, former design professor (1988 to 2016) at the Technological Federal University of Paraná (UTFPR). She began her studies in botanical illustration at the Botanical Illustration Center of Paraná (CIBP) in 2005 and earned her SBA Distance Learning Diploma in 2017, with Distinction.

​

Rogerio Lupo * (Facebook Page: Rogério Lupo - Ilustração Científica)

Microlicia naudiniana

Vellozia albohexandra

Proteopsis sp. nov (hábito e detalhe do capítulo)

A Natural Science Illustrator who graduated in biology from the Universidade de São Paulo. Much of his work is dedicated to the illustration of scientific botanical articles/papers. He has also researched different approaches to illustration and artistic techniques. He has won first prize in several competitions, including the Margaret Flockton Award in 2010 and 2013.

Detail of 'Proteopsis'. Copyright Rogerio Lupo

Lidia Macedo

Vriesia betuminosa​

Gustavo Marigo (Rio de Janeiro) - Margaret Mee scholar at Kew in 2015

Mucuna japira

Tillandsia geminiflora

Billbergia distachia

An award winning natural history and botanical illustrator (MM Scholar 2015). In 2016 he won 2nd prize in the Margaret Flockton Award and had three of his paintings (purchased by Shirley Sherwood) included in 'Brazil - A Powerhouse of Plants' exhibition at the Shirley Sherwood Gallery at Kew. Currently he works on illustration commissions for scientific articles and books and teaches via workshops at the Botanical Garden of Rio de Janeiro plus classes, courses and private lessons.

'Billbergia distachia' Copyright Gustavo Marigo

Laura Montserrat (Facebook)

Aechmea nudicaulis (see below)

Laura graduated from the University of São Paulo (IB-USP) with a Bachelor's degree in Biology. She produces paintings and scientific illustrations of plants and animals.

'Aechmea nudicaulis' Aquarela sobre papel Arches / Watercolour on Arches paper, 31 x 41 cm Copyright Laura Montserrat

Álvaro Nunes *(​b. Annapolis. where he lives and works )

Cecropia sp

Cecropia pachystachia 1 (see below)

Cecropia pachystachia 2

Has dedicated many years to the scientific illustration of wildlife and botanical subjects found in different ecosystems within Brazil including some areas which have not hitherto received much attention. As a result he has received a number of awards for his work. The Shirley Sherwood Collection contains 29 paintings by him. (You can read more about Alvaro in 'Botanical Artists in South America')

'Cecropia pachystachia 1' Copyright Alvaro Nunes

Maria da Penha Passos

Billbergia porteana

Elisabeth Seraphin Prosser (Curitiba)

Tibouchina mutabilis

Heliconia psittacorum

Professor of the School of Music and Fine Arts of Paraná (Unespar), is a social historian of Paraná art. PhD in Environment (UFPR)

​

Maria Alice Rezende * (Rio de Janeiro)

Bonnetia sessilis (SEE ABOVE)

Archytea triflora

Maria graduated from the National School of Fine Arts at Rio de Janeiro University having specialised in Botanical Illustration with the National School of Tropical Botany. She further developed her knowledge and skills when studying for her Postgraduate Diploma at Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew as one of the Margaret Mee International Fellowship in 2004. She has contributed to publications about the native and/or endangered plants and orchids of Brazil

Bonnetia sesssilis by Maria Alice Rezende

Simone Ribeiro

Cattleya guttata

Psidium cattleianum

Ipomoea coccinea

Raquel Rosadas

Vriesea erythrodactylon

Bibiana Rys

Bougainvillea glabra

- Landscaper defending the Brazilian flora. He studied botanical illustration with Cecília Tomasi and Hiroe Sasaki. Has participated in several exhibitions in Brazil (São Paulo, Belo Horizonte and Curitiba).

Hiroe Sasaki * (São Paulo)

Centrolobium tomentosum

Dichorisandra thyrsiflora

Stercula apetala

Born in Japan but has lived in Brazil since 1970. Margaret Mee Scholar in 1991. Works as a freelance artist, undertakes commissions and has exhibited in various exhibitions.

Sterculia apetala (watercolor, 50cm x 35cm) copyright Hiroe Sasaki

Isabel Lima e Silva * (b. Belo Horizonte; currently living in Rio de Janeiro)- Margaret Mee Scholar in 2009

Psittacanthus cinctus

Vriesea gradata

Cattleya forbesii

Suzana Ferreira de Souza

Cyathea delgadii

Highly commended for Cyathea delgadii in the Margaret Flockton Award 2016. Exhibited two botanical illustrations in the 2017 exhibition.

Cyathea delgadii Copyright Suzana Ferreira de Souza

Heliconia psittacorum (watercolour, 56.5cm x 38.5cm) copyright Cecilia Tomasi

Cecilia Tomasi * (São Paulo) - Margaret Mee Scholar 1993. Worked as an illustrator in the Botanical Institute of São Paulo for 30 years (1981-2012). She also taught botanical illustration techniques and was the curator of the collection of illustrations, drawings and paintings. Exhibited and published extensively.

Campomanesia phaea

Heliconia psittacorum

Alexandre Viana

Dickya distachya

Fatima Zagonel *

Collaea speciosa

Cereus jamacaru

Caesalpinia echinata​

Started botanical art in 1998. Margaret Mee Scholar in 1999. Her paintings are in major collections including the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, the Shirley Sherwood Collection, the Hunt Institute and Focus on Nature (New York State Museum). She now helps other aspiring botanical artists.

Cereus jamacaru by Fatima Zagonel
